historicalFigures.name: Pachacuti
historicalFigures.background: Pachacuti was the ninth Sapa Inca. He transformed the Kingdom of Cusco into the Inca Empire (Tawantinsuyu). He is often credited with building Machu Picchu.
keyDecisions: Reorganizing the empire into four suyus.
historicalFigures.legacy: Pachacuti is the Alexander the Great of the Andes. His legacy is written in stone.
quotes: I was born as a lily in the garden, and like the lily I grew.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Machu Picchu is the symbol of Peru.

historicalFigures.name: Túpac Amaru II
historicalFigures.background: Túpac Amaru II was an indigenous leader who led a massive uprising against Spanish colonial rule in Peru. He claimed descent from the last Inca emperor.
keyDecisions: Executing the corregidor Antonio de Arriaga.
historicalFigures.legacy: Túpac Amaru II is the father of Peruvian identity. He is a hero across Latin America.
quotes: There are no accomplices here other than you and I. You as the oppressor, I as the liberator.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His image was used by the revolutionary government. He inspired the Tupamaros.
modernInterpretations: His execution is a symbol of colonial brutality.

historicalFigures.name: Mario Vargas Llosa
historicalFigures.background: Mario Vargas Llosa is a writer and politician. He won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2010. He was a leading figure of the Latin American Boom.
keyDecisions: Running for President in 1990 (losing to Fujimori).
Shifting from left to right politically.
historicalFigures.legacy: Vargas Llosa is the greatest living Peruvian. His novels dissect power and corruption.

historicalFigures.name: Saint Rose of Lima
historicalFigures.background: Rose of Lima was a Dominican tertiary and mystic. She was the first person born in the Americas to be canonized as a saint by the Catholic Church.
achievements: Patron Saint of Peru and the Americas.
First Saint of the New World.
historicalFigures.legacy: Saint Rose is the spiritual mother of Peru. Her shrine is a major pilgrimage site.
quotes: Apart from the cross, there is no other ladder by which we may get to heaven.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her feast day is a national holiday.
modernInterpretations: Her asceticism is viewed through a modern lens.

historicalFigures.name: Miguel Grau
historicalFigures.background: Miguel Grau was a naval officer and hero of the War of the Pacific. Known as the 'Knight of the Seas' for his chivalry, he commanded the monitor Huáscar.
keyDecisions: Commanding the Huáscar against the Chilean navy.
Saving the survivors of the Esmeralda.
Sending condolences to the widow of his enemy (Prat).
Fighting to the death at Angamos.
achievements: Kept the Chilean navy at bay for months.
historicalFigures.legacy: Grau is the greatest hero of Peru. He represents honor and duty.
quotes: I will not return but in victory or death.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Every city has a Grau avenue. A minute of silence is held annually.

historicalFigures.name: José de San Martín
historicalFigures.background: San Martín was an Argentine general who liberated Argentina, Chile, and Peru from Spanish rule. He declared the independence of Peru in 1821.
keyDecisions: Resigning after the Guayaquil Conference (leaving glory to Bolivar).
historicalFigures.legacy: San Martín is the founder of the Peruvian state. His resignation is an act of supreme patriotism.
quotes: From this moment on, Peru is free and independent.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His statue is in the Plaza San Martin.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a father of the nation.
His clash with Bolivar is a historical drama.

historicalFigures.name: Manco Cápac
historicalFigures.background: Manco Cápac was the legendary founder of the Inca dynasty and the city of Cusco. According to myth, he emerged from Lake Titicaca.
keyDecisions: Finding the spot where his golden staff sank (Cusco).
historicalFigures.legacy: Manco Cápac is the Adam of the Incas. He is the root of the empire.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a central figure in Andean mythology.

historicalFigures.name: César Vallejo
historicalFigures.background: César Vallejo was a poet, writer, and journalist. He is considered one of the greatest poetic innovators of the 20th century in any language.
keyDecisions: Supporting the Republicans in the Spanish Civil War.
historicalFigures.legacy: Vallejo is the poet of pain. 'I will die in Paris with a rainstorm' is his prophecy.
quotes: There are blows in life, so powerful... I don't know.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a secular saint of literature.
modernInterpretations: His work is difficult but rewarding.

historicalFigures.name: Yma Sumac
historicalFigures.nativeName: Zoila Augusta Emperatriz Chávarri del Castillo
historicalFigures.background: Yma Sumac was a singer known for her extraordinary vocal range (over four octaves). She was an international exotica star in the 1950s.
keyDecisions: Claiming to be an Inca princess.
historicalFigures.legacy: Yma Sumac is the Peruvian Songbird. She put Peru on the pop culture map.
modernInterpretations: Her 'Inca' persona is seen as camp but empowering.

historicalFigures.name: Javier Pérez de Cuéllar
historicalFigures.background: Javier Pérez de Cuéllar was a diplomat who served as the fifth Secretary-General of the United Nations from 1982 to 1991.
keyDecisions: Mediating the end of the Iran-Iraq War.
Negotiating the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan.
Running for President of Peru (against Fujimori).
Serving as PM in the transition government.
historicalFigures.legacy: Pérez de Cuéllar is Peru's greatest diplomat. He served the world and his country.
quotes: Peace is not just the absence of war.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of integrity.

historicalFigures.name: Gastón Acurio
historicalFigures.background: Gastón Acurio is a chef and ambassador of Peruvian cuisine. He is credited with starting the Peruvian gastronomic revolution.
keyDecisions: Dropping out of law school to cook.
Founding cooking schools for the poor.
achievements: Put Peruvian food on the world map.
challenges: Convincing Peruvians to value their own food.
historicalFigures.legacy: Gastón is the chef who united a nation. Food is now Peru's soft power.
quotes: Cooking is a weapon of mass construction.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is more popular than politicians.
modernInterpretations: His impact on the economy is huge.

historicalFigures.name: Chabuca Granda
historicalFigures.background: Chabuca Granda was a singer and composer of Creole waltzes and Afro-Peruvian rhythms. Her song 'La Flor de la Canela' is the unofficial anthem of Lima.
historicalFigures.legacy: Chabuca is the voice of Lima. Her songs are eternal.

historicalFigures.name: Clorinda Matto de Turner
historicalFigures.background: Clorinda Matto de Turner was a writer and early feminist. Her novel 'Aves sin nido' (Birds Without a Nest) was the first to expose the plight of the indigenous people.
historicalFigures.legacy: Clorinda broke the silence on indigenous abuse. She is a pioneer of social literature.
quotes: I love the race that suffers.

historicalFigures.name: José Carlos Mariátegui
historicalFigures.background: Mariátegui was a journalist and political philosopher. He wrote 'Seven Interpretive Essays on Peruvian Reality', applying Marxism to the Peruvian context.
keyDecisions: Analyzing the 'Indian problem' as an economic one.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mariátegui is the father of Peruvian socialism. His analysis is still debated.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a hero to the left.

historicalFigures.name: Teófilo Cubillas
historicalFigures.background: Teófilo 'Nene' Cubillas is a former footballer. He is considered Peru's greatest player and one of the best midfielders in history.
keyDecisions: Leading Peru to the 1970 and 1978 World Cups.
achievements: South American Footballer of the Year (1972).
challenges: Alianza Lima air disaster (came out of retirement).
historicalFigures.legacy: Cubillas is the face of Peru's golden generation. He is a global legend.
quotes: I treat the ball with affection.

historicalFigures.name: María Reiche
historicalFigures.background: María Reiche was a German-born mathematician who dedicated her life to researching and protecting the Nazca Lines.
keyDecisions: Spending decades in the desert measuring lines.
Sweeping the lines with a broom.
achievements: Proved they were an astronomical calendar.
historicalFigures.legacy: Reiche is the guardian of Nazca. Without her, the lines might be gone.
quotes: The lines are a book written for the gods.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a saint of science.

historicalFigures.name: Daniel Alomía Robles
historicalFigures.background: Daniel Alomía Robles was a composer and ethnomusicologist. He is best known for composing 'El Cóndor Pasa', the most famous Peruvian melody.
historicalFigures.legacy: His melody is the second national anthem. He gave the Andes a voice.
quotes: Music is the soul of the people.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: El Cóndor Pasa is known worldwide.
modernInterpretations: His work is a national treasure.

historicalFigures.name: Santa Rosa de Lima
historicalFigures.background: Rose of Lima was a Dominican tertiary and mystic. She was the first person born in the Americas to be canonized as a saint by the Catholic Church.
achievements: Patron Saint of Peru and the Americas.
First Saint of the New World.
historicalFigures.legacy: Saint Rose is the spiritual mother of Peru. Her shrine is a major pilgrimage site.
quotes: Apart from the cross, there is no other ladder by which we may get to heaven.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her feast day is a national holiday.
modernInterpretations: Her asceticism is viewed through a modern lens.
